title.narrative: WFW - Women Led Peace and Security in Rakhine State

description.narrative: The state of Rakhine is home to one of the three major conflicts in Myanmar: the Rakhine ethnic group (predominantly Buddhist) and the Rohingya Muslim minority. In addition, there are a number of minority ethnic groups who repeatedly are victims of or participants in the conflict. Women for the World and the Indigenous Women's Coalition for Peace work together to create peace in the community through building the capacity for community development and Disaster Risk Reduction through minority ethnic women's savings groups. This project, through trainings, builds the capacity of indigenous women to manage traditional weaving industries, address gender-based violence, increase knowledge in Disaster Risk Reduction and increase their capacity to respond to disasters in order to promote peace in communities of conflict. A total of 1,492 women and men will directly benefit from this project through DRR training, livelihood support after disaster (vegetable seeds, rice seeds, shelter re-construction, fishing nets), community organizing training, advocacy training and meetings and gender-based and sexual violence training. 51,913 persons, connected to these people through their communities and families will be indirectly affected by this project.
